### Executive Summary
> The offside rule has been a topic of debate in the football world for years, with many calling for changes to be made. Arsene Wenger, the former Arsenal manager, has proposed a new offside rule that could potentially debut before the 2026 FIFA World Cup. Despite being rejected by UEFA and IFAB, Wenger's proposal has sparked a lot of interest and discussion among football fans and pundits. In this article, we will delve into the details of Wenger's proposal, the reasons behind its rejection, and the potential implications of its implementation.

## A New Era for Offside Rules
Arsene Wenger's proposal for a new offside rule has been making headlines in the football world. The former Arsenal manager has suggested that a player should be considered offside only if they are in the opponent's half of the field and receive the ball directly from a teammate. This proposal has been met with both praise and criticism, with some arguing that it would improve the game and others claiming that it would create more confusion.

Wenger's proposal is not entirely new, as it is based on a similar rule that was experimented with in the 2019-2020 season. However, the new proposal has some key differences, including the fact that it would only apply to players in the opponent's half of the field. This change is intended to reduce the number of offside decisions and make the game more exciting for fans.

## Mandatory Data Table
### Offside Rule Proposals
| Proposal | Description | Status |
| --- | --- | --- |
| Arsene Wenger's Offside Rule | A player is considered offside only if they are in the opponent's half of the field and receive the ball directly from a teammate | Rejected by UEFA and IFAB |
| 2019-2020 Experiment | A similar rule was experimented with in the 2019-2020 season, but it was not implemented permanently | Not implemented |
| Current Offside Rule | A player is considered offside if they are closer to the opponent's goal line than both the ball and the second-to-last opponent when the ball is played forward | In use |
